title: 4 ways Boeing’s CEO tripped up at Tuesday’s 737 MAX hearing
text:
Knowledge of damning messages

Earlier this month, instant messages between two senior Boeing pilots that had been sent in 2016 burst into public view, focusing sharp attention on what Boeing knew about the 737 MAX and its shortcomings, and when officials knew it.

For instance, former Boeing pilot Mark Forkner wrote that a flight-control feature now at the heart of multiple reviews related to the MAX was “running rampant” in a flight simulator and that he’d “basically lied to the regulators (unknowingly).” And in a separate email exchange, he boasted about “jedi-mind tricking” regulators.

Under pressure from senators Tuesday who wanted to hear what he knew and when he knew it, Muilenburg was unable to do much more than answer that he was aware that his company had submitted the documents to the Justice Department as part of an ongoing investigation, but only learned the details of the exchanges a few weeks ago.

"I was made aware of the existence of this kind of document, this issue, as part of that discovery process in the investigation early in the year," Muilenburg said. "At that point, I counted on my counsel to handle that appropriately."

“That is passive voice and disclaiming responsibility,” said Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), who chairs the Senate Commerce subcommittee in charge of aviation. “You’re the CEO. The buck stops with you."

No commitment to aircraft certification changes

Currently, most aircraft certification tasks are “delegated” to the manufacturer itself, with FAA serving in an oversight role. But multiple probes into the twin 737 MAX crashes and the way the plane was certified have pointed to weaknesses in how the FAA oversees this program, which Congress has expanded at the request of manufacturers like Boeing.

Senators repeatedly tried to get Muilenburg to outline what, if any, changes to the delegation system Boeing could support, largely to no avail.

Muilenburg said he didn’t have “specific recommendations” for any changes the FAA should make, and defended the delegation program as having in fact “enhanced safety.” He noted the industry’s stellar safety record over the past decade and said “a portion of that can be attributed to the [delegation] process." But, he added, "That doesn’t mean we shouldn’t refine and reform it over time.”

However, he declined to outline specifically what refinements may be necessary.

Lobbying on grounding

As most other countries moved to ground the 737 MAX following the second deadly crash in Ethiopia, the United States was among the last to pull the planes from the sky. Media reports suggested that as the administration grappled with the decision, Muilenburg had made a personal appeal to President Donald Trump to keep them flying.

On Monday, Sen. Shelley Moore Capito (R-W.Va.) asked Muilenburg bluntly if reports of Boeing lobbying the U.S. government to continue to allow the MAX to fly were true.

Muilenburg avoided answering directly, saying Boeing reached out to authorities to “understand what happened.”

“We, with the FAA, were pursuing data to make a good safety-based decision. ... When data became available ... again with the FAA, we came to a conclusion that there could be similarities between the two accidents and that led very quickly to a decision to ground the fleet,” Muilenburg said.

That’s similar to the answer the FAA has given — that they made the decision to ground the fleet when there was data suggesting a potential link between the two crashes, one involving an Indonesian Lion Air plane and one involving an Ethiopian Airlines plane.

Pilot error he said/she said

Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) said that after the crashes, Boeing told his office that the accidents “were the result of pilot error.”

“Those pilots never had a chance,” Blumenthal said. “These loved ones never had a chance. They were in flying coffins as a result of Boeing deciding that it was going to conceal MCAS from the pilots.”

Sen. Tom Udall (D-N.M.) also said Boeing “blamed the deceased pilots and the culture of the countries where the crashes occurred.”

“We have not blamed the pilots,” Muilenburg said. “That is not our company position, and it never will be. We are responsible for our airplanes. We are responsible, and we own that, regardless of cause.”
